author: Special Correspondent
text:
Aamby Valley resort was opened only after the group paid Rs. 1 cr, promised to pay the rest soon

Sahara Group found itself in another problem with the Maharashtra government deciding to seal the Aamby Valley Resort for non-payment of dues amounting to Rs. 4.3 crore on Tuesday. The sealed gates, however, were opened later in the day as the company paid Rs. 1 crore and promised to pay up the rest of the sum by March 28 in three instalments, officials said.

Maharashtra Revenue Minister Eknath Khadse said the action was taken under the directive given by the Taluka Tahsildar of Mulshi in Lonavala, after a cheque furnished by the group bounced.

The amount of Rs. 4.3 crore was due as non-agriculture tax to the revenue department, he said. “The Tahsildar has the authority to take these actions under the powers vested with him and does not need to take any directives from the government,” said Mr. Khadse.

Senior officials of the revenue department said portions of the Sahara Group’s flagship project on the outskirts of the Lonavala hill station were sealed in the morning on Tuesday. A team from the local Tahsildar office locked up the main gates and the administrative quarters of the resort, keeping the rear entrance open for giving access to staff and clients. The dues were pending for the past two years, a notice for the same was served to the group warning of legal action. Officials said repeated reminders to the group did not get any results. Finally, a legal notice was served giving them a deadline of March 31, said an official.

According to the group’s website, the resort is spread over 10,600 acres of hilly terrain, and is ‘India’s best planned city and trendsetter in urban planning’.
title: Sahara’s township briefly shut over non-payment of dues
